conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
Identify the velocity-time graph. The graph shows velocity on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. The velocity is given as a function of time.
Determine the velocity at different points on the graph. From the graph, at time 1 second, the velocity is 2 m/s. At time 2 seconds, the velocity is 0 m/s. At time 3 seconds, the velocity is -2 m/s.
Calculate the acceleration using the formula for acceleration: \( a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \).

premise: From the graph, the velocity changes from 2 m/s to 0 m/s and then to -2 m/s.
conclusion: Therefore, the change in velocity is 2 m/s to 0 m/s, and then 0 m/s to -2 m/s.

premise: Since the velocity changes from 2 m/s to 0 m/s, the acceleration is \( \frac{0 - 2}{1} = -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
conclusion: The acceleration is -2 m/s² during the interval from 1 to 2 seconds.

premise: Since the velocity changes from 0 m/s to -2 m/s, the acceleration is \( \frac{-2 - 0}{3 - 2} = -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
conclusion: The acceleration is -2 m/s² during the interval from 2 to 3 seconds.

premise: Since the velocity changes from 0 m/s to -2 m/s, the acceleration is \( \frac{-2 - 0}{3 - 2} = -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
conclusion: The acceleration is -2 m/s² during the interval from 2 to 3 seconds.

premise: The acceleration is constant during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
conclusion: Since the acceleration is constant, the acceleration during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is \( -2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
